p: Male sticklebacks that experienced warm winter temperatures were significantly smaller than the control individuals at the beginning of the breeding season (Figure 1a; Table 1). Standard length showed significant heritable variance, and there was a strong positive genetic correlation across environments (i.e., control and warm winter; Table 1). This cross‐environment genetic correlation significantly differed from 0 and did not differ from 1, indicating that different genotypes showed a fixed plasticity (no G × E) in body size at sexual maturation in this stickleback population (see Fig. S1A).
